I apologize for instigating this conversation and then disappearing! :)

**=
 Some background

I use IDEA (and my current client uses Eclipse).  IDEA ca=
n run tests
in a variety of ways, including all tests across all modules in=
 this
project (a project may have one or more modules).  That's how I
*usua=
lly* run my tests.  We also run our tests from Maven 2 (and
sometimes Ant f=
or older projects).

I'm now realizing that this is a trickier problem than=
 I originally
thought.  It's made more complicated by the fact that most of=
 our
projects are multi-module.  For example, I tried cpsuite and it only
f=
inds tests in a single module.  While I could craft a negation to
exclude "=
*OnlineTest", it wouldn't run all of the tests across
modules.  I looked at=
 JunitExt's Category and it seemed like it only
provided a way to organize =
the result of the tests, not filter which
tests are executed (maybe I misse=
d something).

Thinking out loud:

From Ant and Maven, I can simply use fil=
ename inclusion/exclusion to
exclude my "Online" tests.  The aggregation of=
 tests across modules is
handled by a parent script or pom.  All is general=
ly well from the
command line (for now).

From IDEA, I can use something li=
ke cpsuite (JUnit 4 tests) or JUnit
Addons' DirectorySuiteBuilder (JUnit 3 =
tests).  But there's no way to
run all tests across all modules, excluding =
"*Online*", unless the
JetBrains folks implement this feature
(http://www.j=
etbrains.net/jira/browse/IDEA-13558).

I'm not entirely sure what Eclipse d=
oes to run tests across modules. 
I suspect it has similar limitations.

**=
 Another take on describing an ideal

I guess what I'd find in an ideal wor=
ld is a way to optionally group
test classes (or specific tests) with a tex=
tual group-name and then be
able to pass one or more group-name to a test r=
unner which would then
execute only the tests tagged appropriately.  The te=
st runner would
also support negation so that you could express "not online=
 tests".

Both the Eclipse and IDEA developers could enhance their test run=
ners
to support execution filtering by group.  They would be able to
contin=
ue to provide their special "run all tests across all modules"
feature, and=
 it could apply the group filters across all modules.

** Grouping by class=
 or string?

I don't like the idea of specifying a group using a class beca=
use it
doesn't feel like a class to me.  It's meta-data not code; the fact
=
that it's an empty class has a bit of a smell to me.  The thing I'm
describ=
ing really seems like it's a tag (ala flickr etc) that is used
to organize =
tests.  I like the fact that it's loose (as all tags are)
so that you can e=
stablish a convention across modules without having
to share actual classes=
.  If you want refactor-safety, you could
create a static class with consta=
nts (e.g. @Test(group =3D
TestSuites.DATABASE)).  Users would have the opti=
on. 


So, the thing I realized which is important is that what I'm really
=
looking for is tag/group support in the Eclipse and IDEA custom test
runner=
s (sure, ant and maven would be nice too, it's secondary to me
though).  I =
don't see how a junit extension like cpsuite could solve
the "all tests wit=
h tag 'foo' across all modules" problem.  It's one
level out from there (at=
 the junit ant task, maven surefire, idea, or
eclipse level).  The only way=
 eclipse/idea would support something
like this is if someone writes an ent=
irely new test runner plugin
(seems like a big waste of time) or if the gro=
up/tag feature makes its
way into junit core.  Then all of the various runn=
ers would likely
build in support.

Sorry for the long winded message.  The=
re are a few ideas in here. 
What do you think?

Christian

> It seems ther=

Suite construction (find all the tests I might want

division (only run the tests I actually want to

> 
> *** Suite cons=
truction ***
> 
> It's really important for me that it's clear how to run a=
ll my tests,
> so I've often had to start with an AllTests suite from the v=
ery
> beginning.  Maintaining those suites can be annoying, so in some of m=
y
> projects, I've used Johannes Link's excellent ClasspathSuite:
> 
> http=
://www.johanneslink.net/cpsuite.html
> 
> This allows me to run all tests i=
n a package without having to
> enumerate them.  Eclipse and ant do this "i=
n the UI", but I prefer
> doing it in the suite definition itself, so other=
 developers can run
> my tests without matching the UI.
> 
> *** Suite subd=
ivision
> 
> Once we can find all the tests we might want to run, how do we=

> restrict which are actually run?  There are two out-of-the-box
> solutio=
ns I know of.
> 
> First, I accomplish what you discuss through package org=
anization: I
> can run test.unit.**, test.online.**, or test.** to get ever=
ything.
> This doesn't match every conceivable need, but it does match ever=
y
> need I've had so far.  Would it handle your current situation?
> 
> Sec=
ond, JUnitExt claims to add a @Category annotation that does almost
> exact=
ly what you promise.  Would that handle your situation?  One
> thought I ha=
ve is that perhaps we'd want to base groups on class
> names, so that autom=
ated refactoring can help if we decide to use a
> more informative name, an=
d to provide an obvious place to document and
> extend a category definitio=
n.  That is, rather than
> 
> @Category("online tests") public class MyTest=
 {
> 
> We could have
> 
> @Category(OnlineTests.class) public class MyTest=
 {
> 
> Or even just
> 
> @OnlineTest public class MyTest {
> 
> So, questi=
ons for the community:
> 
> 1) Should something like ClasspathSuite be inco=
rporated into JUnit?
> 2) Should something like JUnitExt's categories be in=
corporated into
JUnit?
> 3) If yes to the above, what should the API look l=
ike?
> 
> Remember that we strive to have JUnit be the intersection of all
=
> useful testing frameworks, not their union.  Thanks,
> 
>    David Saff
